All Known Exoplanets

By Sam Goldman

Exoplanet Viewer Instructions

The website uses data from the NASA Exoplanet Archive to display each of the 4,055 currently confirmed exoplanets. It displays the exoplanets grouped by their star system, with the option to display each roughly to scale to each other. For the sake of screen real-estate, stars are never to scale, nor are the displayed orbits. However, the orbital periods depicted are to scale (values are randomized for any unknown period, about 100 planets).

  1. Viewing these instructions: in the control menu on the right, click the 'instructions' button.
  2. Closing these instructions: click anywhere outside of the modal.
  3. Display parameters: the following instructions involve modifying display parameters. For any of the parameters to take effect, you must click the 'update' button in the menu.
    1. Planetary scale: to toggle planetary scale, use the 'scale' checkbox on the menu. When scale is enabled, use the 'scaleRatio' slider. Planetary scale is determined by the planet's Jovian Radius, so 
      1 pixel = (1 / scaleRatio) * jovian_radii
      .
    2. Stellar Radius: to change the radius of the stars, use the 'stellarRadius' slider.
    3. Sol System: toggle the 'includeSol' checkbox to include the Sol system for reference.
    4. Sort the Systems: to choose a method for sorting the systems, either alphabetically by name or by the number of planets in the system. Toggle the 'ascending' checkbox to switch between ascending or descending sorting.
    5. Systems per Line: adjust the number of systems per row with the 'systemsPerLine' slider. Note that several of the previous parameters impact the overall size of the system. When these are modified, the grid sizes are adjusted to fit the largest system.
  4. Animation: to change the speed of the animation, use the 'timeScale' slide. To toggle the animation on and off, use the 'pause' checkbox.

Credit to this demo for help with the orbital animation code and to W3Schools for the base for this modal.
